confession.devil_appearance: Sometimes appeared black in the form of a man, other times red and yellow; many other demons so diverse in appearance that sometimes one could not remark anything certain
confession.seduction_context: When returning to Aidoile after begging for bread at Dagneville
sabbat_locations: pre dit en Coyes entre les bois du Chapitre d'Espinal
sabbat_activities: dancing to the sound of a drum and flute
banqueting, eating meat without taste or flavor
making reverence to the evil one on arrival
men of higher status uncovered their heads
intermixing with much confusion, crying and making great noise

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to lend grain, claimed he only had enough for own needs

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: next day found ill, later died
two years before, after horse strayed and damaged her land

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to cart hay for her

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: next day became ill 'comme enragé' but recovered after she passed hands over its head and back
next day after refusing to cart hay

testimony.quarrel_subject: Wife sent fish caught at mill to friends living with Ysabeau, but none to Ysabeau herself

harms_alleged.target_relationship: from herd she was keeping for witness

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: multiple incidents but did not particularly suspect her

testimony.threat_quote: qu'on feroit encore quelque chose, mais que les gens estoient trops mal parlans

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: died 8 days before deposition after 9 week illness

testimony.quarrel_subject: Confronted Ysabeau directly, saying several people called her a witch
testimony.threat_quote: que tous les malz disans fussent au devant de leur chemin

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 9 week illness with animal in stomach

witnesses.name: Nicolas Anthoine
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: housemate (shared same house for last 3 years)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Pigs strayed and damaged Ysabeau's crops
Dispute over 'droit de douaire' claimed by mother-in-law from Ysabeau's previous husband's property

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: promptly became unwell, unable to feed baby; recovered after returning next day to tell Ysabeau of illness
recently husband bargained with Ysabeau to undertake pilgrimage to St. Curien on daughter's behalf, but witness did not believe her responsible

testimony.quarrel_subject: Late husband refused to cart wood for Ysabeau some years earlier

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: became ill on 14th or 15th November, subsequently died
same time as horse became ill
became ill after leading horse; said only person she met was Ysabeau

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: Prévôt of Bruyères records request from George Ferry dit bien-nelot who renders himself partie civile; both parties arrested and brought to Bruyères; preliminary interrogation and confession

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: First confession about seduction, sabbat attendance, and malefices against Bietrix and her daughter Mongeote; sent back to prison with exhortation to think about accomplices

timeline.subject: George Ferry dit bien-nelot
timeline.details: Accuser released on condition he return when asked

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: Asked again later that day about other matters; said she had recourse to prayer which prevented enemy making her do other harm. Also stated she saw Bastienne wife of Jean Brihey and Marie wife of Demenge returning from sabbat 3 years before

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: PG des Vosges orders fuller information about her other misdeeds, without prejudice to confession already made

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: Witness depositions taken from 18 witnesses from Aidoile

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: Repeated earlier confessions, made series of further admissions about malefices; confirmed seeing Nicolas from Dompierre (surname Vaney) on way from sabbat; confirmed earlier accusations of two women

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: Change de Nancy concurs with death sentence

timeline.subject: Ysabeau Richard
timeline.details: Prévôt de Bruyères states that bons hommes have confirmed death sentence, which has now been carried out

accomplices_named.name: Bastienne wife of Jean Brihey
accomplices_named.context: Ysabeau said 3 years before, when returning from sabbat, she found herself next to this woman and thought she had been there too; described as 'fort agée' and 'en bruit d'estre sorciere'

accomplices_named.name: Marie wife of Demenge
accomplices_named.context: About 30 years old; Ysabeau found herself next to her returning from sabbat 3 years before and thought she had been there too; was 'en bruit d'estre sorciere'

accomplices_named.name: Nicolas Vaney
accomplices_named.context: Ysabeau said she had seen him on way from sabbat, although had not actually seen him at the assembly itself

prior_accusations.context: Ysabeau's family were 'nottez dudit crime' (noted for the crime of witchcraft)
Had been driven out of her birthplace (Exeguey) according to witnesses
Mother-in-law of witness #8 warned her after marriage about Ysabeau's reputation and told her to avoid quarrels

notable_quotes.speaker: Ysabeau Richard
notable_quotes.french: Qu'elle a esté du depuis souvent au sabbat, qui ordinairement se tenoit le mercredy au pre dit en Coyes entre les bois du Chapitre d'Espinal, avec plusieurs autres qu'elle ne cognoist et en troupe comme on va au marche ou a une feste, et si trouvoit un grand nombre de personne, que les gros et ceux de plus d'apparence estoient preservés, aussy bien audit sabbat, que parmy le monde, et les pauvres pareillement rejestés.
notable_quotes.english: That she had been since then often at the sabbat, which ordinarily was held on Wednesday in the meadow called en Coyes between the woods of the Chapter of Epinal, with several others whom she did not know and in a group as one goes to market or to a feast, and there was found a great number of people, that the fat and those of more appearance were preserved, as well at said sabbat as among the world, and the poor similarly rejected.
notable_quotes.context: Describing the social hierarchy at the sabbat - reflecting earthly class distinctions

notable_quotes.speaker: Ysabeau Richard
notable_quotes.french: les plus riches et apparentez estoient d'ordinaire assis a table, et les plus pauvres comme elle signamment esloignées et rejetés
notable_quotes.english: the richest and most well-connected were ordinarily seated at table, and the poorest like herself particularly distant and rejected
notable_quotes.context: Further describing class divisions at the sabbat

notable_quotes.speaker: Ysabeau Richard (reported threat)
notable_quotes.french: qu'on feroit encore quelque chose, mais que les gens estoient trops mal parlans
notable_quotes.english: that one would do something more, but that people were too evil-speaking
notable_quotes.context: Reported by witness as words said after throwing something over dying child

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie Demenge Jean Priay
notable_quotes.context: How she confronted Ysabeau, telling her several said she was a witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Ysabeau Richard
notable_quotes.french: que tous les malz disans fussent au devant de leur chemin
notable_quotes.english: that all evil-speakers be in front of their path
notable_quotes.context: Threatening gesture during thunderstorm when witness suggested commending themselves to God

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Vincent Vinot of Exeguey
Had been married three times; to Colas Hiey of Exeguey (first marriage)
to Jean de Cugney of Aidoile (second marriage)
widow of Nicolas Demenge Richard, who had died three weeks earlier
Ysabeau and her late husband had lived in same house as them for last 3 years
her husband had let part of house to them
9-year-old daughter Mongeote / Mengeotte fille a la precedente
after her marriage her mother-in-law (who lived at Brouvelieures)
Mongeotte Grounisse, who shared his house
spoken to her about a 'droit de douaire' which her mother-in-law was still claiming
renders himself partie civile against Ysabeau

economic_context.details: Multiple economic tensions: refused loan of grain (witness 1); refused carting services (witnesses 4, 17); dispute over 'droit de douaire' (widow's property rights) from previous husband's estate (witness 15); Ysabeau described as poor and rejected at sabbat; was begging for bread at time of seduction; incident involving fish distribution where she was excluded (witness 6); refused loan of horse (led to malefice confession)

harms_catalog.victim_name: horse belonging to Bietrix widow of Demenge Borion
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Bietrix made public incident three years before when Ysabeau's late husband refused to loan Ysabeau a horse

harms_catalog.harm_description: found ill in stable, later died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jacat refused to lend grain, claiming only had enough for own needs; Ysabeau remarked they claimed to have none but now had plenty

harms_catalog.victim_name: another horse belonging to Jacat Doron
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: horse had strayed and done damage on her land

harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill 'comme enragé' (like rabid), but recovered after Ysabeau passed hands over its head and back
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Nicolas refused to cart hay for her
harms_catalog.method_alleged: cured by passing hands over head and back after being threatened with burning

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow from herd kept by Ysabeau for Claudon Ferry
harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: from herd witness owned, kept by accused
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Claudon's wife sent fish to friends living with Ysabeau but none to Ysabeau herself

harms_catalog.victim_name: horses belonging to household of Mengeon le Duc
daughter aged 7 of Demenge Didier Blot
harms_catalog.harm_description: died after 9 week illness of strange kind, seemed to have some kind of animal in her stomach
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Ysabeau took something from her apron and threw it over the child
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 9 weeks between incident and death; died 8 days before deposition
harms_catalog.method_alleged: threw something from her apron over the child

harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: same time as horse, around November 14-15

only person she had met was Ysabeau

Taken from Ysabeau's house for remedial purposes

weather_events: thunderstorm during pilgrimage 13 years earlier (witness 10 frightened, suggested commending selves to God)

Described as poor and rejected at sabbat
Social hierarchy at sabbat: 'the fat and those of more appearance were preserved, as well at said sabbat as among the world, and the poor similarly rejected'
Rich and well-connected sat at table, poorest like Ysabeau were distant and rejected
Multiple refusals to lend or provide services (grain, horse, carting)
Disputes over widow's property rights ('droit de douaire')
religious_calendar_references: St. Jean (around June 24, when fish incident occurred)

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: sent back to prison with exhortation to think about both malefices and accomplices

hearsay_chains.content: told by Mongeotte Grounisse, who shared his house, that Ysabeau had taken something from her apron and thrown it over the child
after her marriage her mother-in-law warned her of Ysabeau's reputation and told her to avoid quarrels
Mother had told her that Ysabeau had been driven out of her birthplace
Had heard rumour of her reputation six years before, and that she had been chased from previous home
her family were 'nottez dudit crime' (noted for the crime)

emotional_state_notes: said she wished to save her soul, therefore admitted she was a witch
when two witches from Brouvelieures and Docelles had been burned she had been 'sombre et pensive' (somber and pensive), wearing as many clothes as she could, thought she feared the same fate
said she had recourse to prayer when she saw she had been abused, and this had prevented the enemy making her do other harm

extraction_metadata.notes: Very complete trial record with detailed confession about sabbat, including rare sociological details about class distinctions at sabbat (poor vs. rich treatment). Multiple malefices with clear quarrel-harm sequences. No torture used; accused confessed voluntarily claiming to want to save soul. Trial moved quickly from arrest (Nov 17) to execution (Dec 14). Rich detail on economic tensions and property disputes. Accused was poor, begging, and involved in multiple lending/service refusal conflicts. Named three accomplices. Execution confirmed by December 14, 1615.
